captions.text: WHATEVER IT TAKES
So I used to play soccer in the backyard with my brother and two cousins.
Those games were probably some of the most heated of my life.
I used to hate losing that's for sure.
I guess all my earliest memories and when I was a child my football career was here
The school I was at, a few teachers every now and then were like "What are you going to do?"
I just said, "Play football" and they were like "Yeh, but really, what are you going to do?"
I was like, "Yeah, play football!"
THREE YEARS LATER
The first time I was here was actually the day I signed,
The gaffer gave me a bit of a tour around the place.
I walked out here and I guess got my first taste or experience of what it's like to be at Celtic Park.
Our home ground is something that is very special,
I think the atmosphere that's created there is one of the best in the world.
Everyone knows the Green Brigade. Yeh up there in that corner there
And this is the little away section here, which you don't tend to hear too much.
I guess the whole mentality of the fans is different over here and different to what I'm used to.
It really is more than just a game to a lot of them, which I find great.
I feel very fortunate to be able to play football here
It's been an amazing couple of years for me and hopefully I can keep progressing
You know, you go to a new place, a new club and It's hard not to be nervous.
I had a few good words with the gaffer,
You know, they said that they'd done their homework and that they know what I could do
And just to relax
It's a really good bunch of lads which, for me, coming to such a big club I didn't know whether to expect that or not.
The accent isn't an issue for me anymore, but you still come across the odd really strong one which
Sometimes I just smile and nod.
Coming in, in January, it was obviously good to be part a of the squad that won the league and cup double
But, at the same time you do want to contribute more as a player
Every footballer wants to play every game, wants to play as much as they can
But, at the same time, I'm quite realistic with my goals
I understand coming in to a very settled squad in January is going to taking a little bit of time to work my way in to
I want to improve all aspects of my game, there's a lot of things to work on and
I'm confident i'm in the right environment to do that.
I understand and know that this year is very important and a big year in my career, so I think that's exciting.
I know that If I continue working hard and have the right attitude then my opportunity will come.
And then it's just a matter of taking it and seizing my chance.
The past few years have been great, and I've obviously enjoyed it But I feel that for me, 'The Chance' is over
And, I'm obviously in the next chapter of my football career
With where I'm at with Celtic in my club football, and obviously the national team in preparation for next year
I don't think it gets much better than that.

title: Nike Football: Whatever It Takes - Episode One

comments.text:
I live in the US, possibly the most unsupported football country in the 
world. When I was a kid, I had to wait for all the kids playing their 
"football" to finish. I had one friend who liked the sport. That explains 
life to someone who likes this sport in Pennsylvania, USA.﻿
comments.author: Ari Bowman (Walrus)

comments.text:
If you're good, you play academy. I live in the U.S. and play at the 
highest level in the country for youths, and I dont feel that at all. Maybe 
you have to step your game up a bit and come play with the big boys.
comments.author: Matt Surh

comments.text: how do u get scouted﻿
comments.author: huzaifa umar

comments.text:
You have to play at a local Sunday league team near you, then the more you 
develop the higher level team you join. Then scouts come to matches and 
watch you play and if they think you're good enough they'll ask you for a 
trial and if all goes well you'll play for their academy.

comments.author: Hafiz Rayyan

comments.text:
+Hafiz Rayyan I live in that little island seperated from the mainland of 
Australia, it's called Tasmania. With a population of just over 500,000 I 
found the chance to make a name for myself. At the age of sixteen I found 
an opportunity to trial for a scholarship with NSR Australia. I went to the 
trials, got through furthered into an interview which then cleared me. I 
was given the full scholarship to play for a team in the US while getting 
my degree in Architecture. Summary of my experience, there is ALWAYS an 
opportunity around, no matter where you live! Head up man I'm sure if 
you're passionate enough something great will come!

comments.text:
I play every day. I go to the local park where their are 35 to 40 year 
olds, you would think they are out of shape but regardless their age they 
play pretty good, because they go to the park everyday as well. I go and 
play, try to live my dream and be somewhere in life. I feel that god is 
giving me a message because one day nike the chance will be back and when 
it is I will be ready and prepared to live my dream. I'm training hard. I 
will make it become a reality. I honestly want it bad, but instead of 
saying it I try my best to show it more instead. ﻿

comments.text:
Me and Tom are both from the same city and around the same age. Growing up, 
his name was never one of those that you would hear as one of the best 
players. Tuggeranong United was regarded as one of the worse clubs in the 
area. Funnily enough, many of those people who were regarded as the best 5 
or 10 years ago, have fallen by the wayside and Tom's living his dream. I 
too was never regarded as one of the best player, but now I've played all 
over Europe! Apparently Tom worked his ass off before getting his chance. 
Some players are just late bloomers.. Congrats Tom! ﻿

comments.text:
This video just made me wanna go back outside an train even harder. I got 
my ACL ripped off twice. Doctors had told me that i probably wont ever play 
football again. And one of them said that even the pro's train at least 5 
times a week when they get back from an ACL injury, and that we ''normal 
people'' couldn't cope with that. That joke made me so pumped up that since 
that day im training 5 times a week on recovering and getting my football 
skills developed. Never stop working to your goal!
comments.author: DreamChaser

This is truly inspiring. This video has a very important message to send 
out, You`ll see what Tom Rogic is experiencing and behind all this its pure 
hard work. Sure, everyone got talent but not everyone is able to to 
something with it. You have to work with your talent to accomplish your 
dreams, and when your there, living your dream, remember that talent doesnt 
last forever. When you go pro, thats when the real hard work starts. And 
Tom here proves that to us all.
